prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Practical Advice for Protecting Confidential Business Information
Review of Duties and Acknowledgment by Employee

para.paratext: In addition to ensuring that new employees understand that they may be exposed to confidential information, employers should ensure that employees understand their legal obligations with respect to such information. As appropriate, each of the three potential legal obligations related to confidential information—the duty of confidence, restrictive covenants and fiduciary duties—should be carefully reviewed with every employee. Where possible, such duties should be acknowledged by the employee in writing (preferably by way of an executed employment contract or, in the alternative, by a signed letter of acceptance).

Each employee should be reminded of his or her obligation to maintain business information in confidence, to disclose to the employer relevant information developed or learned during the course of employment, to not compete with the employer by intercepting corporate opportunities or customer connections, and to not engage in outside work which places the employer's business or confidential information at risk. Each employee should also receive a written copy of relevant company policies on confidential business information. This includes any employee handbooks, workplace policies, codes of ethics, computer and internet policies, and other conduct guidelines. It is also recommended that employees execute written acknowledgments of receipt of and agreement to such policies. For enforceability purposes, it is important to have these acknowledgments executed prior to or at the time of hiring.
